title: Authors and Citation
text: Shiying Xiao. Author, maintainer. Jun Yan. Author. Panpan Zhang. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Xiao S, Yan J, Zhang P (2024). fcstat: Statistical Methods Functional Connectivity. R package version 0.1.0, https://github.com/Carol-seven/fcstat.
code: @Manual{,   title = {fcstat: Statistical Methods for Functional Connectivity},   author = {Shiying Xiao and Jun Yan and Panpan Zhang},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://github.com/Carol-seven/fcstat}, }

title: fcstat
text: goal fcstat provide classical statistical methods estimating functional connectivity analysis brain networks, making user-friendly useful researchers practitioners field neuroimaging.

title: fcstat
text: can install development version fcstat GitHub :

title: fcstat
code: library(fcstat)  X <- matrix(rnorm(200), 10, 20)  ## Statistical methods for estimating the precision matrix, ## including the estimation and selection process fcstat(X, method = "glasso", crit = "CV", fold = 5)

what: Tuning parameter selection information criteria — criterion
title: Tuning parameter selection information criteria — criterion
text: Provide information criteria selecting tuning parameters.

title: Tuning parameter selection information criteria — criterion
Tuning parameter selection information criteria — criterion
text: hatOmega estimated precision matrix. S sample covariance matrix. n integer specifying sample size. crit string specifying tuning parameter selection criterion use. Available options include: "AIC": Akaike information criterion (Akaike 1973) . "BIC": Bayesian information criterion (Schwarz 1978) . "EBIC": extended Bayesian information criterion (Foygel Drton 2010) . "HBIC": high dimensional Bayesian information criterion (Wang et al. 2013; Fan et al. 2017) . ebic.tuning scalar (default = 0.5) specifying tuning parameter calculate crit = "EBIC".

title: Tuning parameter selection information criteria — criterion
text: scalar.

title: Tuning parameter selection information criteria — criterion
text: Akaike H (1973). “Information Theory Extension Maximum Likelihood Principle.” Petrov BN, Csáki F (eds.), Second International Symposium Information Theory, 267–281. Akad\'emiai Kiad\'o, Budapest, Hungary. Fan J, Liu H, Ning Y, Zou H (2017). “High Dimensional Semiparametric Latent Graphical Model Mixed Data.” Journal Royal Statistical Society Series B: Statistical Methodology, 79(2), 405–421. doi:10.1111/rssb.12168 . Foygel R, Drton M (2010). “Extended Bayesian Information Criteria Gaussian Graphical Models.” Lafferty J, Williams C, Shawe-Taylor J, Zemel R, Culotta (eds.), Advances Neural Information Processing Systems 23 (NIPS 2010), 604–612. Schwarz G (1978). “Estimating Dimension Model.” Annals Statistics, 6(2), 461–464. doi:10.1214/aos/1176344136 . Wang L, Kim Y, Li R (2013). “Calibrating Nonconvex Penalized Regression Ultra-High Dimension.” Annals Statistics, 41(5), 2505–2536. doi:10.1214/13-AOS1159 .

what: Derivative of the non-convex regularization penalty — deriv
title: Derivative of the non-convex regularization penalty — deriv
text: Compute derivative specified non-convex regularization penalty.

title: Derivative of the non-convex regularization penalty — deriv
Derivative of the non-convex regularization penalty — deriv
text: penalty character string specifying non-convex penalty use. Available options include: "adapt": adaptive lasso (Zou 2006; Fan et al. 2009) . "atan": arctangent type penalty (Wang Zhu 2016) . "exp": exponential type penalty (Wang et al. 2018) . "mcp": minimax concave penalty (Zou 2006) . "scad": smoothly clipped absolute deviation (Fan Li 2001; Fan et al. 2009) . Omega precision matrix. lambda scalar specifying regularization parameter. gamma scalar specifying hyperparameter penalty function. defaults : "adapt": 0.5 "atan": 0.005 "exp": 0.01 "mcp": 3 "scad": 3.7

title: Derivative of the non-convex regularization penalty — deriv
text: numeric matrix.

title: Derivative of the non-convex regularization penalty — deriv
text: Fan J, Feng Y, Wu Y (2009). “Network Exploration via Adaptive LASSO SCAD Penalties.” Annals Applied Statistics, 3(2), 521–541. doi:10.1214/08-aoas215 . Fan J, Li R (2001). “Variable Selection via Nonconcave Penalized Likelihood Oracle Properties.” Journal American Statistical Association, 96(456), 1348–1360. doi:10.1198/016214501753382273 . Wang Y, Fan Q, Zhu L (2018). “Variable Selection Estimation using Continuous Approximation \(L_0\) Penalty.” Annals Institute Statistical Mathematics, 70(1), 191–214. doi:10.1007/s10463-016-0588-3 . Wang Y, Zhu L (2016). “Variable Selection Parameter Estimation Atan Regularization Method.” Journal Probability Statistics, 2016, 6495417. doi:10.1155/2016/6495417 . Zou H (2006). “Adaptive Lasso Oracle Properties.” Journal American Statistical Association, 101(476), 1418–1429. doi:10.1198/016214506000000735 .

title: Estimation for precision matrix — fcstat.est
text: Provide collection statistical methods obtain series precision matrix estimates across grid tuning parameters.

title: Estimation for precision matrix — fcstat.est
code: fcstat.est(   X,   method,   base = "cov",   lambda = NULL,   nlambda = 20,   lambda.min.ratio = NULL,   gamma = NULL,   target = 0,   initial = "glasso",   utilopt = "flare",   cores = 1 )

title: Estimation for precision matrix — fcstat.est
text: X n--p data matrix sample size n dimension p. p--p sample covariance/correlation matrix dimension p. method character string specifying statistical method estimating precision matrix. Available options include: "glasso": graphical lasso (Friedman et al. 2008) . "ridge": graphical ridge (van Wieringen Peeters 2016) . "elnet": graphical elastic net (Zou Hastie 2005) . "clime": constrained L1-minimization inverse (covariance) matrix estimation (Cai et al. 2011) . "tiger": tuning-insensitive graph estimation regression (Liu Wang 2017) , applicable X n--p data matrix. "adapt": adaptive lasso (Zou 2006; Fan et al. 2009) . "atan": arctangent type penalty (Wang Zhu 2016) . "exp": exponential type penalty (Wang et al. 2018) . "mcp": minimax concave penalty (Zou 2006) . "scad": smoothly clipped absolute deviation (Fan Li 2001; Fan et al. 2009) . base character string (default = "cov") specifying calculation base, either covariance matrix ("cov") correlation matrix ("cor"). applicable X n--p data matrix. lambda Grid non-negative scalars regularization parameter. default NULL, generates lambda sequence based nlambda lambda.min.ratio. nlambda integer (default = 20) specifying number lambda values generated lambda = NULL. lambda.min.ratio scalar specifying fraction maximum lambda value \(\lambda_{max}\) generate minimum lambda \(\lambda_{min}\). lambda = NULL, program automatically generates lambda grid sequence length nlambda log scale, starting \(\lambda_{min}\) \(\lambda_{max}\). default value 0.4 method = "clime", 0.1 method = "tiger" 0.01 methods. gamma Grid scalars specifying hyperparameter chosen method. Default values: "elnet": sequence 0.1 0.9 increments 0.1 "adapt": 0.5 "atan": 0.005 "exp": 0.01 "scad": 3.7 "mcp": 3 target p--p symmetric matrix scalar (default = 0) serves value elements, specifying target matrix method = "ridge" method = "elnet". initial p--p matrix p--p--npara (number combinations lambda gamma) array specifying initial estimate method set "atan", "exp", "scad", "mcp"; specifying \(\tilde{\Omega}\) adaptive weight method = "adapt", calculated \(|\tilde{\omega}_{ij}|^{-\gamma}\), \(\tilde{\Omega} := (\tilde{\omega}_{ij})\). options also offered character string provided (default "glasso"), including: "glasso": use precision matrix estimate derived graphical lasso. "linshrink": use precision matrix estimate derived Ledoit-Wolf linear shrinakge estimator population covariance matrix (Ledoit Wolf 2004) . "nlshrink": use precision matrix estimate derived Ledoit-Wolf non-linear shrinakge estimator population covariance matrix (Ledoit Wolf 2015; Ledoit Wolf 2017) . "invS-glasso": use inverse calculation base matrix matrix invertible; otherwise, use precision matrix estimate derived graphical lasso. "invS-linshrink": use inverse calculation base matrix matrix invertible; otherwise, use precision matrix estimate derived Ledoit-Wolf linear shrinakge estimator population covariance matrix (Ledoit Wolf 2004) . "invS-nlshrink": use inverse calculation base matrix matrix invertible; otherwise, use precision matrix estimate derived Ledoit-Wolf non-linear shrinkage estimator population covariance matrix (Ledoit Wolf 2015; Ledoit Wolf 2017) . utilopt character string specifying utility option use method = "clime": "clime_primaldual": utility function clime package clime linsolver primaldual. "clime_simplex": utility function clime package clime linsolver simplex. "flare": utility function sugm package flare. cores integer (default = 1) specifying number cores use parallel execution.

title: Estimation for precision matrix — fcstat.est
text: object S3 class "fcstat.est" containing following components: hatOmega list estimated precision matrices lambda grid gamma grid. lambda actual lambda grid used program, corresponding hatOmega. gamma actual gamma grid used program, corresponding hatOmega. X n--p data matrix used program. S p--p calculation base matrix used program.

title: Estimation for precision matrix — fcstat.est
text: method tiger, estimation process solely relies raw n--p data X utilize argument base. argument applicable tiger effect provided.

title: Estimation for precision matrix — fcstat.est
text: Cai TT, Liu W, Luo X (2011). “Constrained \(\ell\)1 Minimization Approach Sparse Precision Matrix Estimation.” Journal American Statistical Association, 106(494), 594–607. doi:10.1198/jasa.2011.tm10155 . Fan J, Feng Y, Wu Y (2009). “Network Exploration via Adaptive LASSO SCAD Penalties.” Annals Applied Statistics, 3(2), 521–541. doi:10.1214/08-aoas215 . Fan J, Li R (2001). “Variable Selection via Nonconcave Penalized Likelihood Oracle Properties.” Journal American Statistical Association, 96(456), 1348–1360. doi:10.1198/016214501753382273 . Friedman J, Hastie T, Tibshirani R (2008). “Sparse Inverse Covariance Estimation Graphical Lasso.” Biostatistics, 9(3), 432–441. doi:10.1093/biostatistics/kxm045 . Ledoit O, Wolf M (2004). “Well-Conditioned Estimator Large-Dimensional Covariance Matrices.” Journal Multivariate Analysis, 88(2), 365–411. doi:10.1016/S0047-259X(03)00096-4 . Ledoit O, Wolf M (2015). “Spectrum Estimation: Unified Framework Covariance Matrix Estimation PCA Large Dimensions.” Journal Multivariate Analysis, 139, 360–384. doi:10.1016/j.jmva.2015.04.006 . Ledoit O, Wolf M (2017). “Numerical Implementation QuEST Function.” Computational Statistics & Data Analysis, 115, 199–223. doi:10.1016/j.csda.2017.06.004 . Liu H, Wang L (2017). “TIGER: Tuning-Insensitive Approach Optimally Estimating Gaussian Graphical Models.” Electronic Journal Statistics, 11(1), 241–294. doi:10.1214/16-EJS1195 . van Wieringen WN, Peeters CFW (2016). “Ridge Estimation Inverse Covariance Matrices High-Dimensional Data.” Computational Statistics & Data Analysis, 103, 284–303. doi:10.1016/j.csda.2016.05.012 . Wang Y, Fan Q, Zhu L (2018). “Variable Selection Estimation using Continuous Approximation \(L_0\) Penalty.” Annals Institute Statistical Mathematics, 70(1), 191–214. doi:10.1007/s10463-016-0588-3 . Wang Y, Zhu L (2016). “Variable Selection Parameter Estimation Atan Regularization Method.” Journal Probability Statistics, 2016, 6495417. doi:10.1155/2016/6495417 . Zou H (2006). “Adaptive Lasso Oracle Properties.” Journal American Statistical Association, 101(476), 1418–1429. doi:10.1198/016214506000000735 . Zou H, Hastie T (2005). “Regularization Variable Selection via Elastic Net.” Journal Royal Statistical Society Series B: Statistical Methodology, 67(2), 301–320. doi:10.1111/j.1467-9868.2005.00527.x .

what: Statistical methods for estimating precision matrix — fcstat
title: Statistical methods for estimating precision matrix — fcstat
text: Provide collection statistical methods estimate precision matrix.

title: Statistical methods for estimating precision matrix — fcstat
code: fcstat(   X,   method,   base = "cov",   n = NULL,   lambda = NULL,   nlambda = 50,   lambda.min.ratio = NULL,   gamma = NA,   target = 0,   initial = "linshrink",   utilopt = "flare",   crit = "CV",   fold = 5,   ebic.tuning = 0.5,   cores = 1 )

title: Statistical methods for estimating precision matrix — fcstat
text: X n--p data matrix sample size n dimension p. p--p sample covariance/correlation matrix dimension p. method character string specifying statistical method estimating precision matrix. Available options include: "glasso": graphical lasso (Friedman et al. 2008) . "ridge": graphical ridge (van Wieringen Peeters 2016) . "elnet": graphical elastic net (Zou Hastie 2005) . "clime": constrained L1-minimization inverse (covariance) matrix estimation (Cai et al. 2011) . "tiger": tuning-insensitive graph estimation regression (Liu Wang 2017) , applicable X n--p data matrix. "adapt": adaptive lasso (Zou 2006; Fan et al. 2009) . "atan": arctangent type penalty (Wang Zhu 2016) . "exp": exponential type penalty (Wang et al. 2018) . "mcp": minimax concave penalty (Zou 2006) . "scad": smoothly clipped absolute deviation (Fan Li 2001; Fan et al. 2009) . base character string (default = "cov") specifying calculation base, either covariance matrix ("cov") correlation matrix ("cor"). applicable X n--p data matrix. n integer (default = NULL) specifying sample size. required input matrix X p--p sample covariance/correlation matrix dimension p. lambda Grid non-negative scalars regularization parameter. default NULL, generates lambda sequence based nlambda lambda.min.ratio. nlambda integer (default = 50) specifying number lambda values generated lambda = NULL. lambda.min.ratio scalar specifying fraction maximum lambda value \(\lambda_{max}\) generate minimum lambda \(\lambda_{min}\). lambda = NULL, program automatically generates lambda grid sequence length nlambda log scale, starting \(\lambda_{min}\) \(\lambda_{max}\). default value 0.4 method = "clime", 0.1 method = "tiger" 0.01 methods. gamma Grid scalars specifying hyperparameter chosen method. Default values: "elnet": sequence 0.1 0.9 increments 0.1 "adapt": 0.5 "atan": 0.005 "exp": 0.01 "scad": 3.7 "mcp": 3 target p--p symmetric matrix scalar (default = 0) serves value elements, specifying target matrix method = "ridge" method = "elnet". initial p--p matrix p--p--npara (number combinations lambda gamma) array specifying initial estimate method set "atan", "exp", "scad", "mcp"; specifying \(\tilde{\Omega}\) adaptive weight method = "adapt", calculated \(|\tilde{\omega}_{ij}|^{-\gamma}\), \(\tilde{\Omega} := (\tilde{\omega}_{ij})\). options also offered character string provided (default "linshrink"), including: "glasso": use precision matrix estimate derived graphical lasso. "linshrink": use precision matrix estimate derived Ledoit-Wolf linear shrinakge estimator population covariance matrix (Ledoit Wolf 2004) . "nlshrink": use precision matrix estimate derived Ledoit-Wolf non-linear shrinakge estimator population covariance matrix (Ledoit Wolf 2015; Ledoit Wolf 2017) . "invS-glasso": use inverse calculation base matrix matrix invertible; otherwise, use precision matrix estimate derived graphical lasso. "invS-linshrink": use inverse calculation base matrix matrix invertible; otherwise, use precision matrix estimate derived Ledoit-Wolf linear shrinakge estimator population covariance matrix (Ledoit Wolf 2004) . "invS-nlshrink": use inverse calculation base matrix matrix invertible; otherwise, use precision matrix estimate derived Ledoit-Wolf non-linear shrinkage estimator population covariance matrix (Ledoit Wolf 2015; Ledoit Wolf 2017) . utilopt character string specifying utility option use method = "clime": "clime_primaldual": utility function clime package clime linsolver primaldual. "clime_simplex": utility function clime package clime linsolver simplex. "flare": utility function sugm package flare. crit string (default = "CV") specifying parameter selection method use. Available options include: "AIC": Akaike information criterion (Akaike 1973) . "BIC": Bayesian information criterion (Schwarz 1978) . "EBIC": extended Bayesian information criterion (Foygel Drton 2010) . "HBIC": high dimensional Bayesian information criterion (Wang et al. 2013; Fan et al. 2017) . "CV": k-fold cross validation negative log-likelihood loss. fold integer (default = 5) specifying number folds used crit = "CV". ebic.tuning scalar (default = 0.5) specifying tuning parameter calculate crit = "EBIC". cores integer (default = 1) specifying number cores use parallel execution.

title: Performance measures — performance
text: list containing following components: Fnorm1 Frobenius (Hilbert-Schmidt) norm true estimated precision matrices. Fnorm2 Frobenius (Hilbert-Schmidt) norm product true covariance matrix estimated precision matrix identity matrix. KL Kullback-Leibler divergence true estimated precision matrices. Ql Quadratic loss diagonal elements product true covariance matrix estimated precision matrix. Snorm Spectral (operator) norm difference true estimated precision matrices. Precision Precision measure, ratio true positives total predicted positives. Recall Recall measure, also known Sensitivity, ratio true positives total actual positives. Specificity Specificity measure, ratio true negatives total actual negatives. F1 F1 score, harmonic mean Precision Recall. MCC Matthews correlation coefficient, measure quality binary classifications.
